header.excerpt: An interactive 3D portfolio that transforms professional content into a magical wizard laboratory, with floating crystal for projects, mystical book for blogs, and more...
header.title: Magic Portfolio

data.overview:
An immersive 3D experience that transforms a traditional developer portfolio into a magical wizard laboratory, where every interactive object invites you to discover more about me and my work.
Built to be fully dynamic, we can create new themes, from arcane workshop to cosmic observatory or tranquil forest, allowing the portfolio to evolve with new moods and aesthetics.
data.content:
Why I Built It

I've always believed that making lots of projects is the best way to learn. Sure, theory is the foundation you can rely on, but if that were all I'd be doing, I'd just be a reflection of a book. Or many books. But in any case, I think I've conveyed the concept.

Every project helps you grow: you can learn a new programming language, or a new library, or old theoretical concepts rediscovered in practice to enhance the content you're creating. Of course, you can also make a lot of mistakes, which in turn help you understand how to improve.

But after building all those projects, I realized something important: it’s not just about creating, but also about sharing what I create: giving ideas a stage where they can evolve.

Showcasing my work helps me refine my thinking: every time I explain a project, I see it more clearly, uncover new possibilities, and often discover ways to make it better.
It reminds me that innovation doesn’t happen in isolation, but instead it grows through curiosity, feedback, and the courage to make your process transparent.

That’s why I wanted to build a portfolio.

Why not a traditional one?

I could have gone for a traditional, elegant portfolio, clean grid, pastel gradients, big typography… but then I thought that if I want to stand out, I can’t just be elegant in a standard way.

So instead, I decided to make something interactive and alive and, above all, mine.
A place that feels like stepping into a magical world where every project and idea takes physical form.

Of course, for visitors who prefer something more conventional, I’ve also included a classic content view. Let’s call it the “for the serious folks” version.

The Development Journey

The idea was to design an interactive 3D environment, a wizard’s laboratory, where each object represents a piece of me and my work:

  • A floating crystal for projects: the heart of the scene, a floating fragment that draws all the attention

  • An alchemy cauldron for work in progress: always bubbling with new experiments, a reminder that growth is a process of constant refinement.

  • A book on the lectern for blog posts: resting open and alive, whispering stories, reflections, and lessons learned along the journey.

  • A magic circle for collaborations: a shared space of energy and connection, where creativity flows between minds.

  • An illuminated bookshelf for learning paths: each book a doorway to new knowledge and skills.

  • An owl for fun facts: the wise but playful guardian of the room, carrying sparks of personality and humor.

Each item reacts to the player’s hover interactions, revealing content in real time.
It’s playful, intuitive, and instantly memorable.

From Vue Experiments to Full System

I built the project using Vue 3 + TypeScript, partly because I wanted to explore a new frontend framework and add it to my tech stack.
Vue’s reactivity and component model made it perfect for building a dynamic, interactive scene.

The first prototype was just a proof of concept: a few 3D models in a room, floating lights, and placeholder interactions.

[PoC]

But as soon as I started working on the “alchemist’s room”, I realized something:
hardcoding all the project data inside the code was… well, a terrible idea.

So I began thinking about how to manage the content properly.
That’s how my next project was born: GitCMS (for a more detailed explanation, read that project’s page).
In short: I built my own content management system, powered by GitHub.

A Living Environment

As the project grew, I wanted the visuals to feel real and consistent.
I found several 3D models on Sketchfab, all released under Creative Commons Attribution (CC BY) licenses, which means they can be used and modified freely, as long as the original authors are credited.

Some of the models I modified personally in Blender, cleaning up geometry, retexturing, and restructuring the scene so I could easily add interactive elements later.
This hands-on 3D work became a really rewarding part of the process: I didn’t remember knowing how to use Blender!

Refactoring

Once the core environment was working, I started to generalize the whole system.
I wanted Magic Portfolio to be extendable: easy to reskin or expand with new themes later.

So, I removed the early “hardcoded magic” that I’d used just to get something running,
and replaced it with a structured system for managing objects, lights, and particle effects in a modular way.

Now, everything is data-driven and reproducible, meaning future versions could easily feature different worlds, like a space observatory or a library floating in the clouds.

Architecture and Design Evolution

From the very beginning, I envisioned Magic Portfolio as a self-contained and future-proof project: a place where content could live dynamically, without the need for a traditional backend.

In the earliest design drafts, I explored a hybrid structure with a lightweight backend to manage content updates and interactions.
But as I developed GitCMS, I realized that the same goal could be achieved far more elegantly through a fully frontend-driven approach.

By leveraging Git-based data and static generation, the portfolio became dynamic without complexity:
it could read and render content directly from a repository, updating seamlessly while remaining entirely static.
This approach not only simplified deployment — it aligned perfectly with the philosophy behind GitCMS and my long-term goal of creating tools that are both powerful and transparent.

Now, the portfolio runs completely in the browser, hosted anywhere — even on GitHub Pages — yet it remains rich, interactive, and always up to date.

It’s proof that with the right architecture, simplicity can be smarter than scale.

Open Source Philosophy

Magic Portfolio is proudly open source.
I wanted it to be more than a personal project — a resource that others can learn from, remix, and adapt for their own creative journeys.

Sharing the code openly felt like a natural extension of what the portfolio itself represents:
curiosity, transparency, and the belief that ideas grow stronger when they’re shared.

Anyone can explore how the 3D environment works, how the content structure is organized, or even build their own themed version — whether that’s a sci-fi lab, a celestial library, or something completely new.

What I Learned

This project is to always remind me that learning doesn’t stop when a project is finished.

Building new things is essential, but so is learning how to present them: how to give them a story, a personality, and a place where they can shine.

Enjoy the Magic!

Take a look around, you are in the Magic Portfolio!
